body.p: In June 2005, a CBS News/NY Times poll asked a random sample of 1,111 U.S. adults the following question: "What do you think is the most important problem facing this country today?" Roughly 19% of those sampled answered "the war in Iraq" (while the rest answered economy/jobs, terrorism, healthcare, etc.). Exactly a year prior to this poll, in June of 2004, it was estimated that roughly 1 out of every 4 U.S. adults believed (at that time) that the war in Iraq was the most important problem facing the country.

We would like to test whether the 2005 poll provides significant evidence that the proportion of U.S. adults who believe that the war in Iraq is the most important problem facing the U.S. has decreased since the prior poll.
The following output is available for this test:
Which of the following is the best conclusion based on the output?

input.choice: We have extremely strong evidence to reject H0.
We have extremely strong evidence to reject Ha.
We have moderately strong evidence to reject H0.
There is a probability of 0 that H0 is correct.
There is a probability of 0 that Ha is correct.

response.feedback: Correct. A p-value so small (the statistical software reports that it is 0) indicates that it would essentially be almost impossible to obtain data like those observed had H0 been true. This is extremely strong evidence to reject H0.

Incorrect. Remember that a small p-value indicates that the observed data would be rare if the null hypothesis were true. Also, we generally reject the null hypothesis or fail to reject the null hypothesis rather than rejecting the alternative hypothesis (Ha).
Incorrect. Although we do have evidence suggesting that we should reject H0, the evidence is much stronger than moderate.

Incorrect. A p-value represents the probability of obtaining data at least as extreme as the observed given that the null hypothesis is true. If the p-value is low, it does not mean that the null hypothesis is incorrect; it just means that the obtained data is very rare if it comes from the assumed distribution.
Incorrect. Unless you can poll the entire population, there is no way to determine whether or not the alternative hypothesis is true.

body.p: An automatic coffee machine dispenses cups of coffee whose volume per cup varies normally with the mean μ = 10 oz. A quality-control researcher randomly selects 8 cups of coffee from the machine and finds that in this sample the mean volume is 9.92 oz. and the standard deviation is 0.23 oz.
Which of the following represents the correct conclusion we can make based on the output (and at the usual significance level of 0.05)?

input.choice: The data provide enough evidence to reject H0 and to conclude that the mean volume per cup is lower than the target level of 10 oz.
The data provide enough evidence to accept H0 and to conclude that the mean volume per cup is at the target level of 10 oz.
The data do not provide enough evidence to reject H0, so we accept it, and conclude that the mean volume per cup is at the target level of 10 oz.
The data do not provide enough evidence to reject H0, nor to conclude that the mean volume per cup is lower than the target level of 10 oz.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Notice that the p-value is greater than 0.05. This indicates that there is not enough evidence to suggest that the mean amount of coffee per cup is less than 10 ounces.
Incorrect. We never accept the null hypothesis, but rather reject or fail to reject H0.
Incorrect. You are correct that the data do not provide enough evidence but we never accept the null hypothesis, but rather reject or fail to reject H0.
Correct. Since the p-value is relatively large (p = 0.179), the only conclusion that we can draw is that the data does not provide enough evidence to reject H0.

body.p: Which of the following facts about the p-value of a test is correct?

input.choice: A p-value smaller than the significance level provides enough evidence to reject H0.
Regardless of the significance level, a p-value of 0.01 provides enough evidence to reject H0.
The larger the p-value, the more evidence the data provide against H0.

response.feedback: Correct. You are correct that a p-value smaller than the significance level provides enough evidence to reject H0. Since the p-value is the probability of obtaining a sample like that observed (or even more extreme) assuming that H0 is true, a p-value smaller than the significance level means that it is not likely that the null hypothesis is true.
Incorrect. A p-value of 0.01 is enough evidence to reject H0 only if the significance level is greater than 0.01.

Incorrect. Since the p-value is the probability of obtaining a sample like that observed (or even more extreme) assuming that H0 is true, if the p-value is larger than that it means that it is more likely that the null hypothesis is true.

body.p: A manufacturer of bedding wants to do quality control on its 400-thread-count sheets. The thread count varies normally with a mean thread count μ = 400 and a standard deviation σ = 8. A quality control researcher randomly selects 16 sheets and finds that the mean thread count for the sample is 395.2.
We want to determine if these data provide enough evidence to conclude that the mean thread count is significantly different from the target level.

ul.li: One-sample z-test of μ = 400 vs. μ ≠ 400

body.p: Which of the following represents the correct conclusion we can make on the basis of the output (and at the usual significance level of 0.05)?

input.choice: The data provide enough evidence to reject H0 and to conclude that the mean thread count is different than the target level of 400.
The data provide enough evidence to accept H0 and to conclude that the mean thread count is at the target level of 400.
The data do not provide enough evidence to reject H0, so we accept it, and conclude that the mean thread count is at the target level of 400.
The data do not provide enough evidence to reject H0 nor to conclude that the mean thread count is different than the target level of 400.

Incorrect. We never accept the null hypothesis, but rather reject or fail to reject H0. Also, the p-value was 0.0164, so we do have enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis.
